results.title: Lichtspiel Schwarz-Weiss-Grau
results.brief_description:
In 1930, after eight years of research and experimentation, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy created the Light Space Modulator, a kinetic sculpture of rotating glass, spirals and perforated metal sheets illuminated by 140 different light sources. In this same year, he produced the film Lightplay Black White Grey, a dynamic cinematic abstraction of the light and movement generated by the Light Space Modulator. The play of light in the film, as in the original sculpture, enabled Moholy-Nagy to create an altogether new experience for the viewer, asserting his own proposition that,
“Because light is a spatial-temporal problem, the mere accentuation of the question of light brings us into the field of a new spatial awareness that cannot yet be fully analysed. We can, however, find a word to describe it: floating.”
Moholy-Nagy also saw his Light Space Modulator as an extension of the ideas underpinning cinema - magnified light projected on a surface in dynamic configurations. As such, Lightplay Black White Grey, his cinematic mediation of these spatial and light concerns is a vital work in his artistic practise. The film begins as a series of abstract images of geometric shapes and shadows formed by the kinetic movement of the Light Space Modulator. The circular movements of the sculpture and camera in combination provide a pendulous, hypnotic effect that is both a document of the sculpture and an elegant visual dance of shape-shifting forms and transformed light. The rhythmic combinations of stasis and dynamism across altered variations of screen space and superimpositions of motion and form makes for a vertiginous visual experience.
Although it cannot replicate the immersive experience of the light sculpture, the film creates a viewing space in which the audience is visually disoriented by Moholy-Nagy’s spatial dislocations. As the artist anticipated, this creates a sensation of detachment, of ‘floating’, amid a dynamic vision of light’s relationship to spatial understanding.

results.title: Lichtenstein in London
results.creator_credit: Bruce Beresford and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: In February 1968, an exhibition of the paintings of the American pop artist Roy Liechtenstein was held at the Tate Gallery in London. This is a film record of the exhibition and both members of the public and Liechtenstein comment on the work displayed. The public were interviewed by Hugh Evans. Roy Liechtenstein’s comments were taken from interviews by Alan Soloman recorded for National Education Television and by David Sylvester recorded for British Broadcasting Corporation.

results.title: Lichfield: a symphony in stone
results.brief_description: A study of Lichfield Cathedral, famous for its three spires, the central one of which was ruined in the Civil War, but afterwards restored. Illistrates archetecture, constructional details, carving and statues of the Cathedral.

results.title: Licensed to drive (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Jeff regains his licence after losing it for drink-driving. He is determined to keep it this time and has to find ways of sticking to the zero limit. Eventually he is able to meet the challenge of going to a party and enjoying himself without alcohol. He can keep to his decision : “When I drink I don’t drive and when I drive I just don’t drink”.

results.title: Licence to kill (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: John Glen, Michael G. Wilson, Albert R. Broccoli, United Artists Corporation and Danjaq
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
The happy nuptials of James’ CIA buddy Felix Leiter (David Hedison) and bride-to-be Della are rudely interrupted when they embark on a mercy dash to capture drug lord Franz Sanchez (Robert Davi). Thanks to some aerial fishing though, their mission is successful and the parachuting groomsmen make it in time for the wedding. The happy couple are soon devastated however when Sanchez escapes and kills the bride and maims the groom as payback. This triggers best buddy James (Timothy Dalton) to relinquish his secret service status and licence to kill authority (Bond is under orders to complete another mission) as he embarks on a personal vendetta to revenge Sanchez’s brutality towards his friends. Ably assisted by ex-Army pilot Pam Bouvier (Carey Lowell), Bond flies into Isthmus City to infiltrate himself into Sanchez’s posse where he discovers a television evangelist (Wayne Newton) providing a front for cocaine dealing. Featuring a plethora of water inspired stunts earlier on in the film, the cast also includes Benicio Del Toro as a brooding henchman and Talisa Soto as Lupe Lamore, Sanchez’s mistress, eye candy, and source of jealousy for Bouvier. This was Timothy Dalton’s last appearance as Bond.

results.title: Library organization
results.brief_description: Explains the card cataloguing system and the Dewey decimal system in use in one typical library and shows how more detailed understanding of library organisation speeds up work in the library and makes for better studying and better use of study time.

results.title: Library on wheels
results.creator_credit: Bill MacDonald, Gudrun Parker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Behind the library van, making its three-weekly 750-mile circuit of British Columbia’s beautiful Fraser Valley, lies the story of twenty-one communities pooling their resources to solve the problems of bringing books to the people in scattered isolated farming areas. The library van is greeted at every stop by eager borrowers - farmers, fishermen, lumbermen, engineers, adults and children alike. Books are important to all the people of Canada, and the people of the Fraser Valley have made sure that the books they want are readily available to meet their needs. Librarians for the vans are trained at the University of Toronto at the McGill University, Canada.

results.title: Library of Congress
results.creator_credit: United States. Office of War Information
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “The American Scene”.
An account of the scope and methods of operation of the Library of Congress at Washington. Science, painting, music, literature and history are shown as some of the interests of the Institution. The library’s contents include valuable historical documents, newsreel records of outstanding events and personalities, Braille and talking books (on disc) for the blind, in addition to much material of general public interest. Includes a concert performance of music from manuscript collection and library staff in the field recording little known folk musicians.

results.title: Libraries without bars
results.brief_description: Shows modern improvements being made in Japanese libraries to stimulate interest in reading and to encourage appreciation of art, music and literature. Special aspects of the work of these libraries include film programs, radio listening, children’s Saturday afternoon film programs, music rooms and collections of recorded music, art exhibitions, puppet plays, bookmobile services in country districts and many other activities.
